Sure, here are 7 sites in Buenos Aires with interesting stories behind them that could be included in a walking tour:

1. Plaza de Mayo - This iconic plaza is the site of many of Argentina's political demonstrations and has been the center of political life in Buenos Aires since the city's founding in the 16th century. It's also home to the Casa Rosada, the presidential palace where Evita Perón famously addressed the crowds.
2. Teatro Colón - This stunning opera house is considered one of the finest in the world and has hosted many of the world's greatest performers. It was opened in 1908 and has undergone several renovations and restorations since then.
3. Recoleta Cemetery - This famous cemetery is the final resting place of many of Argentina's most notable figures, including Eva Perón, former presidents, and Nobel Prize winners. The cemetery's elaborate mausoleums and monuments are a testament to the wealth and power of Argentina's elite.
4. Palacio Barolo - This unique building was designed by Italian architect Mario Palanti and completed in 1923. It was inspired by Dante's Divine Comedy and is said to represent the journey from Hell to Heaven. The building was once the tallest in Buenos Aires and has stunning views of the city.
5. Caminito - This colorful street in the neighborhood of La Boca is a popular tourist destination and a symbol of Buenos Aires. The buildings are brightly painted in different colors and it's a great place to see tango dancers and street performers.
6. San Telmo Market - This historic market is one of the oldest in Buenos Aires and has been operating since 1897. It's a great place to find antiques, handmade crafts, and traditional Argentine foods. On Sundays, there's also a popular flea market in the area.
7. Avenida de Mayo - This grand avenue is lined with beautiful buildings, cafes, and shops. It was designed to resemble the grand boulevards of Paris and was once the center of Buenos Aires' high society. It's a great place to stroll and take in the city's architecture and culture.
Can you create a walking tour itinerary within the central area of Buenos Aires

Sure, here's an itinerary for a walking tour within the central area of Buenos Aires:

1. Start at Plaza de Mayo - Take in the historic plaza and the iconic Casa Rosada presidential palace.
2. Walk down Avenida de Mayo - Marvel at the architecture of the grand avenue, which was inspired by the boulevards of Paris.
3. Visit Café Tortoni - Stop at the historic café, which has been in operation since 1858 and has hosted many of Argentina's famous writers and artists.
4. Explore the San Telmo neighborhood - Stroll through the cobblestone streets and admire the colonial architecture.
5. Visit the San Telmo Market - Check out the historic market and sample some traditional Argentine foods.
6. Walk to the nearby Mercado de las Pulgas - This flea market is open on weekends and is a great place to find antiques and vintage items.
7. Visit the Obelisk - This iconic monument was built in 1936 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the city's founding.
8. Walk to Teatro Colón - Admire the stunning architecture of the opera house, which is considered one of the finest in the world.
9. End the tour in the Recoleta neighborhood - Take in the elegant streets and visit the famous Recoleta Cemetery, where many of Argentina's most notable figures are buried.

This walking tour is approximately 5.5 km (3.4 miles) and can take between 2-4 hours depending on how long you spend at each site.
Are there some less well-known spots along the way with interesting stories?

Yes, there are many less well-known spots along the way in Buenos Aires that have interesting stories. Here are a few examples:

1. The Kavanagh Building - Located on Avenida Florida, this art deco skyscraper was completed in 1936 and was the tallest building in Latin America at the time. It was built by Corina Kavanagh, an Irish-Argentine heiress who defied her family's wishes to marry a man from a lower social class.
2. The Palacio de los Patos - Located in the Monserrat neighborhood, this neo-gothic building was built in 1890 and was originally the headquarters of a wealthy family. It's said that the family was so wealthy that they would feed their pet swans champagne.
3. The Confitería Ideal - Located in the San Nicolás neighborhood, this historic tango hall was opened in 1912 and has hosted some of the most famous tango dancers in Buenos Aires. It's a great place to watch tango performances or take a tango lesson.
4. The Palermo Viejo neighborhood - This trendy neighborhood is known for its hip bars, restaurants, and street art. It's also home to the Palermo Soho and Palermo Hollywood neighborhoods, which are popular with young people and artists.
5. The Palacio Barolo - As mentioned earlier, this unique building was designed by Italian architect Mario Palanti and completed in 1923. It was inspired by Dante's Divine Comedy and is said to represent the journey from Hell to Heaven.

These spots can easily be added to the walking tour itinerary and can provide a more off-the-beaten-path experience for visitors.
